DOC.HEAD: House Members Call For Sharing Burden Of Asian Defense
DOC.TEXT: Four House members called on the Bush administration Tuesday to encourage U.S. allies in Asia to share more of the defense burden and suggested channeling the savings to developing nations in the area. ``As the Koreans and Japanese pick up more of the U.S. costs, some of this money can be put to work nurturing our alliances elsewhere,'' said Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas. ``Access and influence are the name of the game in the Pacific and we can use all of the friends we can find.'' He said military assistance to Thailand, which hosted more than 100 U.S. Navy ships last year, has bottomed out. Leath, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, and three other colleagues on the panel _ Reps. David O'B. Martin, R-N.Y., Solomon P. Ortiz, D-Texas, and H. Martin Lancaster, D-N.C. _ traveled to the Pacific region Dec. 5-16 to assess national security interests. In a report the lawmakers noted that the cost of maintaining U.S. forces in Asia has increased sharply. South Korea has been the source of a major increase due to a pay hike for the Korean work force. ``Sometimes I wonder if we are more interested in providing for their social security or our national security,'' Leath said. ``Money's tight and getting tighter, and we no longer can affort to be the benevolent Uncle Sam.'' Martin, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services subcommittee on military installations and facilities, said Japan has ``accelerated their contributions to the U.S. presence both in terms of salaries for Japanese employees and facilities.''
